Well of course a GFCI outlet is spewing heat. The whole point of the thing is that it has bimetallic resistors built in and always eating up some of the energy by resisting current and becoming warm. Short out that outlet, trip the GFCI breaker, and you'll see it cool off in a hurry.

Hi, quick note: IR light is also used to detect electrical faults. If your GFCI is showing 70* F with nothing plugged in (while the rest of the wall is clearly cooler), that's not super dangerous but might indicate an incipient problem. Please compare with other GFCI outlets in the building, and if that one is always warmer, please consult a licensed electrician.

We live in Wisconsin, and I walk the kids to school most mornings. Some cold mornings it is hard to get them moving. This spawned 2 discussions: 1. Could we model the conditions to determine what the optimal walking speed is such that increased internal warmth (especially circulating to the face) overrides the increased relative windchill from increased speed (which is noticeable)

2. If we walk a mile, what speed expends least energy considering propulsion and body heat regulation given the varied duration

About the IR glowing electrical socket (6:47 ). Chances are that wasn't current heating the socket. Previously you could see the beams in the wall through the drywall. These beams are typically metal and you could see them because they were hotter than the interior of the building. So the interior space in the wall is hotter than the outside. It is more probable that a pressure difference is forcing the hot air out through the socket.

"solving crimes" is a bit overrated, but there are incredible applications in firefighting. One time at the training they explained to us, that it is possible to tell if there were any other passengers in an vehicle involved in an accident.
Imagine, there was an accident with three persons in the car. All of them are seriosly injured but one manages to get out of the car and tires to get help. He breaks down a few hundred meters away in a field/forrest.
With an infrared-camera, the firefighters can see the warmth of his body on the seat for 30 minutes or so. (I don't remember exactly, but it was incredibly long) So they can send out a search team and save his life.

The outlet glows because it's a GFI outlet. The circuit is routed through a sensing component that monitors the difference in amperage.

Also, there is usually a small light that illuminates when the outlet trips.

So you're not seeing "leaky" power or electricity losses. You're looking at a safety component as it was designed.

We use this all the time in firefighting. Sometimes to find a hot spot to detect hidden fires or fire sources and sometimes after the fire is out and we need to be sure everything has cooled sufficiently so nothing ignites later. Electrical outlet was not "inefficient", it was a GFCI (ground fault circuit interrupter) and uses resistors and other components to detect or limit current.  Current flowing through resistors causes/emits heat.  Normal unused outlets will not emit heat.

The heat you saw at 6:50 from the receptacle is from the outside because the box is not insulated. The reason the studs in the wall show is because they transfer the heat from outside better than the insulation between them. If you look at the shots at the door the glass is 80 degrees, but the metal frame parts are conducting the outside heat. I'm guessing that the temp outside is at least 85 degrees. As a retired electrician we used infrared cameras to detect bad wiring especially at circuit breakers and motor controls. Hot spots usually indicated a bad connection causing higher resistance and thus heat.

Gotta say I use one of these daily for work and your description of it is in some ways misleading. First it can not see through walls. It can only see the surface of items. When you see the studs it's because they warm the surface not because you are seeing (through) the wall. Second it's always relative to what's around it. The scale of the temperature and the colors you see don't always have the same meaning. I.E. The outlet may not be as inefficient as it looks on camera.

The heat coming from that outlet did not occur due to electrical losses. It was heat coming into the building through the wall and into the outlet box, showing up the same way you were seeing the studs inside the wall. An outlet with nothing plugged into it has no current flowing through it, therefor no electrical losses.

Hello! Just wanted to leave a note about this infrared camera and some of its quirks. The sharp crisp lines on the picture are actually due to a visible camera paired with the infrared. Infrared light doesn’t usually give you crisp detail, so this camera combines the visible light image to give detail to the picture. ALSO! The app recalibrates and changes which colors correspond to which temperatures depending on what the min and max temperature are on screen. And lastly, though this may have become obvious over the course of the video, the particular filter we used showed “hotter” as yellow and “colder” as purple. Happy physicsing!
